Random thought I just had about VSLA and wanted to ponder on here with you. How would we formalize the process of combining a number of tensors of the same rank together to create a higher rank tensor ex; bundle multiple 3d tensors over some unit time into a 4d tensor then aggregate those 4d tensors into 5d tensors as needed for the system as many levels up as is useful.

**Formalizing tensor stacking**

Mapping out the formalization of combining multiple tensors into higher rank tensors, including variable shapes and dynamic stacking.

**Formulating structure**

I'm working on defining a 4D ragged tensor by stacking 3D tensors along a new time axis, considering shape semiring, equivalence class, and a grouping operator.

**Confirming file status**

Clarifying that the v2 paper file is outdated and cannot be cited. Moving forward with detailed definitions and algebraic properties, including asynchronous stacking and associativity.

Below is a selfâ€‘contained proposal for extending **Variableâ€‘Shape Linear Algebra (VSLA)** with a *stacking* (or *bundling*) operator that turns a collection of rankâ€‘*r* tensors into a rankâ€‘*râ€¯+â€¯1* tensor, together with a recursive scheme for building arbitrarily deep â€œtensor pyramidsâ€ from a stream of data.

---

## 1â€ƒNotation Recap

* `ğ•‹_r`â€ƒVSLA equivalence class of rankâ€‘*r* tensors  
* `shape(ğ±)`â€ƒvector of extents of ğ± after promotion into a common ambient shape  
* `deg(ğ±)`â€ƒmaximum extent (unchanged from the paper)  

All VSLA operations preserve the **zeroâ€‘padding equivalence** relation: two concrete arrays are equivalent if they become identical after padding out missing elements with neutral zeros.

---

## 2â€ƒThe Stacking OperatorÂ `Î£`

### 2.1â€ƒSignature  
For *kâ€¯â‰¥â€¯1* define  

\[
Î£_k : (ğ•‹_r)^k \;\longrightarrow\; ğ•‹_{\,r+1}.
\]

Intuitively, `Î£_k` concatenates its *k* arguments along a fresh leading axis.

### 2.2â€ƒRepresentative Construction  
Given representatives  
\[
A^{(1)},\dots,A^{(k)} \;\subset\; \mathbb{K}^{n_1^{(i)}\times\dots\times n_r^{(i)}},
\]
choose the ambient shape  

\[
\mathbf{n} = \left(\max_{i} n_1^{(i)},\dots,\max_{i} n_r^{(i)}\right),
\]

pad each \(A^{(i)}\) out to `shape = ğ•Ÿ`, then form the block tensor  

\[
\bigl( Î£_k(A^{(1)},\dots,A^{(k)}) \bigr)_{i,\mathbf{j}} =
   \begin{cases}
     A^{(i)}_{\mathbf{j}}, & 1\le i\le k,\; \mathbf{j}\le \mathbf{n},\\[2pt]
     0,                    & \text{otherwise}.
   \end{cases}
\]

The equivalence class of this representative is the result.  
*Neutral element.*  For `kâ€¯=â€¯0` define `Î£_0 â‰” 0_{ğ•‹_{r+1}}`.

### 2.3â€ƒAlgebraic Properties  

| Law | Proof Sketch |
|-----|--------------|
| **Associativity (nested levels).**  \(\Sigma_m(\Sigma_k(\mathbf{A}),\Sigma_k(\mathbf{B}))\) is equivalent to \(\Sigma_{mk}(\mathbf{A},\mathbf{B})\) after reshaping the first axis. | Follows from blockâ€‘matrix associativity; padding commutes with reshaping. |
| **Neutralâ€‘zero absorption.**  Injecting VSLA zeros anywhere in the argument list leaves the class unchanged. | Zero representatives contribute only zero blocks. |
| **Distributivity over `+`, `âŠ™` (semiring product).** | Promote operands to common ambient shape, then apply ordinary tensor algebra blockâ€‘wise. |

These laws make \((ğ•‹_r,â€¯+,â€¯Î£)\) a **strict monoidal category** where `Î£` is the tensor product on objects of type â€œlist of rankâ€‘*r* tensorsâ€.

---

## 3â€ƒFrom Streams to Tensor Pyramids

### 3.1â€ƒWindowâ€‘Stacking OperatorÂ `Î©`

Let `w âˆˆ â„•âº` be a fixed *window length*.  
For an *infinite* or *finite* stream  

\[
(\, X^{(0)},X^{(1)},\dots\,) \subset ğ•‹_r
\]

define

\[
Î©_w\bigl(X^{(t)}\bigr)_{s} \;=\; Î£_w\bigl(X^{(sw)},\dots,X^{(sw+w-1)}\bigr) 
       \;\in\; ğ•‹_{\,r+1}, \quad s=0,1,\dots
\]

That is, slide a window of lengthâ€¯*w* with **stepâ€¯w** (nonâ€‘overlapping) and stack the contents.

### 3.2â€ƒRecursive Aggregation

Compose `Î©` repeatedly with (possibly different) window sizes \(w_1,w_2,\dots,w_d\):

\[
X^{(0)} \;\xrightarrow{Î©_{w_1}}\; ğ•‹_{r+1}
           \;\xrightarrow{Î©_{w_2}}\; ğ•‹_{r+2}
           \;\dots\;
           \xrightarrow{Î©_{w_d}}\; ğ•‹_{r+d}.
\]

Each level aggregates lowerâ€‘level tensors into the next rank, giving a *dâ€‘level tensor pyramid*.  The process terminates when:

* the application demands no further aggregation, or  
* the time horizon is exhausted (<â€¯`w_d` elements remain).

---

## 4â€ƒImplementation Hints (CÂ +Â Python Bindings)

| Concern | Suggestion |
|---------|------------|
| **Type construction.** Provide a cheap `vsla_stack(vsla_vec_t* list, size_t k)` returning a **view** over contiguous pointersâ€”no data copy if children already share a shapeâ€‹â€‹; else allocate a new contiguous buffer. |
| **Streaming API.** Expose a stateful `vsla_window_accum(state*, X)` that appends incoming tensors, and emits a stacked tensor whenever `countâ€¯==â€¯w`. |
| **Rankâ€‘polymorphic wrappers.** Generate thin C macros and Python overloads: `stack(*xs, axis=0)`; if `axis==0` call VSLA native, otherwise fall back to padding + reshape. |
| **Memory layout.** Keep child blocks in an **arrayâ€‘ofâ€‘pointers** table so growth along the new axis is *O(1)* amortised (similar to ragged nestedâ€‘tensor strategy). |

---

## 5â€ƒComplexity

*Given* \(k\) rankâ€‘*r* operands of total element count \(N\)\*:  

| Operation | Time | Extra Memory |
|-----------|------|--------------|
| `Î£_k` (stack) | `Î˜(N)` if shapes equal; `Î˜(N + kÂ·Î”)` where `Î”` = zeros copied when padding | `Î˜(k)` pointer table + padding |
| `Î©_w` sliding stream | **Amortised Î˜(N)** over the stream; no extra copies if buffering window reuses memory | `Î˜(w)` queue |

\*In the VSLA model, *N* counts only *materialised* (nonâ€‘zero) elements.

| Location | Addition |

| **Paper Â§3 (â€œOperationsâ€).** Insert Definitionâ€¯`Î£` after semiring products; prove monoidal category lemma in appendix. |

| **Benchmarks.** Add `bench/stack_vs_pad.py` comparing VSLA stacking vs naÃ¯ve `torch.stack(pad(xs))`. |

## 7â€ƒOpen Questions & Possible Extensions

1. **Overlapping windows**â€”replace stepÂ *w* with strideÂ `<â€¯w`; provable relationship to *dilated* stacking?  
2. **Reduction instead of raw stacking**â€”parameterise `Î©` with a reduction op (mean, sum, max) to keep rank constant.  
3. **Gradient sparsity**â€”for autograd, do stacked zeros create vanishingâ€‘gradient blocks that need masking?  

---

### TL;DR

Add a *stacking operator* `Î£` that (i) pads inputs to a common shape, (ii) concatenates along a fresh leading axis, and (iii) satisfies associativity, zeroâ€‘absorption, and distributivityâ€”making VSLA a monoidal category. ### Is it redundant?

* **For a numericalâ€‘linearâ€‘algebra audience:**

* **For an ML / systems audience:**  
  Many practitioners **use** FFTâ€‘based 2â€‘D convolutions via cuDNN without ever having seen the asymptotic argument spelled out.  Explicitly calling out the complexity reduction serves three purposes:

[L1] Contemporary challengesâ€”adaptive neural
[L2] networks, multi-resolution signal analysis, dynamic
[L3] meshesâ€”demand structures whose shapes evolve in
[L4] real time.
[L5] Running Example: Consider training a convolutional neural network where filter widths adapt
[L6] dynamically based on input complexity. A standard 3 Ã— 3 convolution kernel K1 = [1, âˆ’1, 2] might
[L7] expand to K2 = [1, âˆ’1, 2, 0, 1] for high-resolution
[L8] features. Traditional frameworks require manual
[L9] padding: Kâ€²
[L10] 1 = [1, âˆ’1, 2, 0, 0] before operations, losing semantic information and incurring unnecessary
[L11] computation on artificial zeros.
[L12] Existing approaches fall short:
[L13] Âˆ TensorFlow Ragged Tensors: Handle
[L14] variable-length sequences but lack rigorous
[L15] algebraic structure and semiring properties.
[L16] Âˆ PyTorch NestedTensors: Provide dynamic
[L17] shapes but without mathematical guarantees or
[L18] efficient sparse representations.
[L19] Âˆ Manual zero-padding: Obscures mathematical structure, wastes computation, and lacks
[L20] provable algebraic identities.
[L21] 1 <PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 2 / 2> 1.2 The VSLA Solution
[L22] VSLA incorporates the shape directly into every
[L23] algebraic object through mathematically rigorous
[L24] equivalence classes. Operations such as addition or
[L25] convolution implicitly coerce operands to a common
[L26] dimension while preserving sparsity and algebraic
[L27] properties. In our example, K1âŠ•K2 = [2, âˆ’2, 4, 0, 1]
[L28] automatically, with provable semiring laws and efficient sparse computation.
[L29] 2 Mathematical Foundations
[L30] VSLA is built on the concept of dimension-aware
[L31] vectors, which treat dimension as intrinsic data
[L32] rather than a fixed constraint.
[L33] Core Definition
[L34] A dimension-aware vector is an equivalence class [(d, v)] where d âˆˆ N is the logical
[L35] dimension and v âˆˆ R
[L36] d
[L37] is the data vector. Two
[L38] vectors (d1, v1) and (d2, v2) are equivalent iff
[L39] their zero-padded extensions to max(d1, d2)
[L40] dimensions are equal.
[L41] This equivalence relation enables automatic shape
[L42] compatibility while preserving mathematical rigor.
[L43] 3 Implementation and Performance
[L44] Our C99 implementation provides two computational models:
[L45] Model A (Convolution Semiring): Uses FFTbased convolution for commutative operations.
[L46] Achieves O(mndmax log dmax) complexity for matrixvector operations.
[L47] Model B (Kronecker Product Semiring): Uses
[L48] tiled Kronecker products for non-commutative operations. Provides cache-optimal memory access patterns.
[L49] 4 Experimental Results
[L50] Benchmarks demonstrate significant performance
[L51] improvements:
[L52] Âˆ FFT convolution: 3-16Ã– speedup vs. direct
[L53] methods
[L54] Âˆ Memory efficiency: 20-50
[L55] Âˆ Development complexity: 10-50Ã– reduction in
[L56] code lines
[L57] 5 Conclusion
[L58] VSLA provides the first mathematically rigorous
[L59] framework for variable-shape linear algebra, enabling principled computation on dynamic tensor
[L60] structures. The open-source implementation demonstrates both theoretical soundness and practical performance benefits.
[L61] Our approach enables new architectures for adaptive
[L62] AI systems, multi-resolution signal processing, and
[L63] scientific computing applications where traditional
[L64] fixed-dimension approaches fall short.
[L65] AI Tools Disclosure
[L66] This research extensively utilized AI assistants from
[L67] Claude (Anthropic), Gemini (Google), and ChatGPT (OpenAI) for theoretical development, implementation, and exposition while maintaining human
[L68] oversight of all scientific contributions.

[L1] Core Definition
[L2] A dimension-aware vector is an equivalence class [(d, v)] where d âˆˆ N is the logical
[L3] dimension and v âˆˆ R
[L4] d
[L5] is the data vector. Two
[L6] vectors (d1, v1) and (d2, v2) are equivalent iff
[L7] their zero-padded extensions to max(d1, d2)
[L8] dimensions are equal.
[L9] This equivalence relation enables automatic shape
[L10] compatibility while preserving mathematical rigor.
[L11] 3 Implementation and Performance
[L12] Our C99 implementation provides two computational models:
[L13] Model A (Convolution Semiring): Uses FFTbased convolution for commutative operations.
[L14] Achieves O(mndmax log dmax) complexity for matrixvector operations.
[L15] Model B (Kronecker Product Semiring): Uses
[L16] tiled Kronecker products for non-commutative operations. Provides cache-optimal memory access patterns.
[L17] 4 Experimental Results
[L18] Benchmarks demonstrate significant performance
[L19] improvements:
[L20] Âˆ FFT convolution: 3-16Ã– speedup vs. direct
[L21] methods
[L22] Âˆ Memory efficiency: 20-50
[L23] Âˆ Development complexity: 10-50Ã– reduction in
[L24] code lines
[L25] 5 Conclusion
[L26] VSLA provides the first mathematically rigorous
[L27] framework for variable-shape linear algebra, enabling principled computation on dynamic tensor
[L28] structures. The open-source implementation demonstrates both theoretical soundness and practical performance benefits.
[L29] Our approach enables new architectures for adaptive
[L30] AI systems, multi-resolution signal processing, and
[L31] scientific computing applications where traditional
[L32] fixed-dimension approaches fall short.

[L1] <PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 1 / 2> Variable-Shape Linear Algebra: Mathematical Foundations
[L2] and High-Performance Implementation
[L3] Royce Birnbaum
[L4] royce.birnbaum@gmail.com
[L5] Independent Researcher
[L6] July 17, 2025
[L7] Abstract: Variable-Shape Linear Algebra
[L8] (VSLA) treats dimension as intrinsic data
[L9] rather than a rigid constraint. This paper makes five concrete contributions: (1)
[L10] formalization of VSLA through equivalence
[L11] classes of finite-dimensional vectors modulo
[L12] trailing-zero padding; (2) construction of two
[L13] semiring instantiationsâ€”convolution and Kronecker productsâ€”with complete algebraic characterization; (3) introduction of the stacking operator Î£ that builds higher-rank tensors from collections of variable-shape tensors,
[L14] forming a strict monoidal category and enabling tensor pyramid constructions for streaming data; (4) asymptotic complexity analysis
[L15] showing FFT-accelerated convolution achieves
[L16] O(mndmax log dmax) for matrix-vector operations compared to O(mnd2
[L17] max) for naive approaches; (5) an open-source C99 library with
[L18] Python bindings. Unlike existing ragged tensor frameworks (TensorFlow Ragged, PyTorch
[L19] NestedTensors), VSLA provides mathematically rigorous semiring structures with provable algebraic identities, enabling principled
[L20] dimension-aware computation for adaptive AI
